org.val: We build reliable, secure, scalable cloud services with a high bar for engineering quality and ownership.
org.grow: There are strong opportunities to grow in scope, technical depth, and leadership.
org.tone: warm, direct, highly technical but conversational

must: Strong programming fundamentals (data structures, algorithms, debugging)
nice: AWS service familiarity (IAM, networking, compute, storage, observability)

prof.exp: Backend engineer (5y). Built APIs and event-driven services; hands-on with testing and incident response.
prof.cv_summary: Recent work includes building a rate-limited API gateway, a queue-driven worker system, and a metrics/alerting pipeline. Comfortable with Python/Java and production operations.
notes: Prioritize a code walkthrough early; probe operational ownership and reliability tradeoffs.

q_add: Most important: Please share your screen and open a code sample you wrote (preferably production or a realistic side project). Walk me through what it does and why you designed it that way.
As you walk through it: explain how you handle errors, retries, edge cases, and input validation. Show tests (or explain your testing strategy if tests aren’t in the repo).
Pick one concrete function/module and refactor it live for readability or robustness (small change is fine). Talk through tradeoffs.
Tell me about one production incident related to similar code: what happened, how you diagnosed it, what you changed to prevent recurrence.
mtg.style: After brief intro, move quickly to screen-share/code walkthrough. One question at a time.

dims.name: Code Quality & Craft
dims.a5: Clean design, strong testing, great tradeoffs

inst: Do not ask for proprietary/confidential code. If they mention it, ask for a sanitized or personal project sample.
If screen share is not possible: ask them to paste a short snippet (30–80 lines) and walk through it.
Keep evaluation hidden; focus on evidence and concrete examples.
